The '''2011 United Kingdom anti-austerity protests''' were a series of [[anti-austerity protests]] that took place in the [[United Kingdom]] in early 2011. While agreeing that the country faced a financial crisis, organisations including some UK [[trade unions]], argued that the [[United Kingdom coalition government (2010âpresent)|Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government]] was pushing deep spending cuts rapidly and without proper consultations or consideration for the impact on the public. They believed that most of the government cuts were targeting workers, while big businesses, and financial businesses in particular, were going unpunished, despite the latter being the main reason for the [[Late-2000s financial crisis|financial crisis]] and the subsequent [[Late-2000s recession|recession]].<ref>http://gulfnews.com/business/opinion/london-faces-a-summer-of-strike-chaos-over-austerity-1.829578</ref>
Earlier demonstrations led to a major event, the ''[[March for the Alternative]]'', on March 26, 2011 coordinated by the [[Trades Union Congress]] with a crowd of 500,000 people taking to [[London]]'s streets.<ref name="Time 110326 Anti-cuts">[http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/26/anti-cuts-march-for-the-alternative-draws-500000-protestors-in-london/ Anti-cuts March for the Alternative draws 500,000 protestors in London]; Time Magazine - News Feed; 26 March 2011</ref><ref name=live>{{Cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/8407260/TUC-protest-march-live.html|title=TUC protest march: live|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=26 March 2011|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|first1=Patrick|last1=Sawer|first2=Laura|last2=Donnelly|first3=Michael|last3=Howie|first4=David|last4=Barrett|first5=Ben|last5=Leach}}</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/society/blog/2011/mar/26/march-for-the-alternative-live-blog-updates March for the Alternative Updates]; The Guardian; 26 March 2011</ref>
Further smaller demonstrations led up to a second big event, ''J30'', on June 30. This was marked by major rallies in [[London]], [[Brighton]], [[Sheffield]], [[Birmingham]] and [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], and massive strike actions by teachers and public sector workers.
==Background== In May 2010, the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|United Kingdom general election]] resulted in no political party achieving sufficient support to form a working majority government on their own. For this reason, the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] and [[Liberal Democrats|Liberal Democratic Party]] entered into [[United Kingdom coalition government (2010âpresent)|a coalition government]] together. The Conservative leader [[David Cameron]] became Prime Minister whilst Liberal Democrat leader [[Nick Clegg]] became Deputy Prime Minister.
The government planned to put into action sharp spending cuts, stating that they were necessary to address the UK's record peacetime [[Government budget deficit|deficit]], with the UK finance minister, [[George Osborne]], saying that Britain risks suffering a debt crisis like those seen in [[Greece]], [[Ireland]] and [[Portugal]] if it fails to reduce the budget deficit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/UPDATE-1-Osborne-Euro-zone-targetukfocus-1207082316.html?x=0 |title=UPDATE 1-Osborne: Euro zone crisis shows debt dangers for UK - Yahoo! UK & Ireland Finance |publisher=Uk.finance.yahoo.com |date=7 April 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> The cuts that they planned proved to be the toughest in the United Kingdom since the [[Second World War]].<ref name="AP London">{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/mobile/?type=story&id=2014609127&st_app=ip_news_lite|agency=Associated Press - London|title=In London, 250,000 march to protest sharp cutbacks |first1=Meera|last1=Selva|first2=Aaron|last2=Edwards|deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=November 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> The new administration has proposed an [[austerity]] program intended to fight the nation's debts, virtually eliminating budget deficits by 2015. The planned spending cuts include most government departments, which involves around 300,000 public service jobs ending and other civil servants receiving pay freezes.
The organisers of the protest say that the Government's plans to eliminate the deficit in four years, and to focus on cutting spending rather than raising tax, do not have national support. They say they want to give a voice to all the people affected by the cuts, and to demonstrate to Westminster that the public rejects the argument that there is no alternative. They and many protesters argue that the cuts will threaten the country's economic recovery.<ref name=abc/><ref name="Time 110326 Anti-cuts" /><ref name="AP London"/> They suggest that since the government recently spent billions bailing out indebted banks,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2008/oct/08/creditcrunch.marketturmoil | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Credit crunch (Business),Business,Market turmoil,World news,UK news,Economic policy,Politics,Banking (Business sector),Financial crisis (Business) | date=30 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=487951&in_page_id=2 |title=Bank of England: Bailout bill over Â£1 trillion |publisher=This is Money |date=26 June 2009 |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> the government should create new taxes for banks and close loopholes that allow some companies to pay less tax. Labour MP Chuka Umuuna declared that it was "shocking" to learn that Barclay's Bank paid only 1% of its 2009 profits in taxes while the corporate tax in the UK is 28%. Max Lawson, of the Robin Hood Tax Campaign, said: "If banks paid their fair share we could avoid the worst of the cuts and help those hit hardest by the financial crisis they did nothing to cause."<ref name="AP London"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2011/feb/18/barclays-bank-113m-corporation-tax?INTCMP=SRCH | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Jill | last=Treanor | title=Barclays (Business),Banking (Business sector),Banks and building societies (UK consumer),Business,Tax and spending,Tax avoidance (Business),Money | date=18 February 2011}}</ref> Dave Prentis, general secretary of [[UNISON]], remarked that "These are ordinary families and working people, many with their children to send a strong message to David Cameron to halt the damaging cuts which are leading to the loss of tens of thousands of jobs and the closure of services including libraries and care homes."<ref name=live/>
The march followed the [[2010 UK student protests|student protests]] of November and December 2010, which focused on cuts and changes to the funding of higher and further education in England. A previous student protest had descended into violence when students attacked the automobile in which [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and his wife [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]] were riding.<ref name=abc>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/27/3174735.htm?section=justin|title=Anti-austerity protesters descend on London|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=27 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> According to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', the protests represent "the biggest public backlash against the Government's spending cuts since it came to power."<ref name=live/>
==January and February protests== On 29 January, the NCAFC (National Campaign Against Cuts & Fees) held a small protest in London. Some minor violence was reported. In Manchester there was a protest of around 5000 people called by the TUC, UCU and the NUS against fees and cuts, billed as "a future that works" rally.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2011/jan/29/student-protesters-nus-president | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Tracy | last=McVeigh | title=Student protesters target NUS president | date=29 January 2011}}</ref> On 1 February, a disused building at the [[University of Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] was occupied and re-opened as the [[Free Hetherington]] anti-cuts space. It has since attracted much controversy due to heavy-handed attempts to evict the students, staff and community members from the building, which resulted in multiple injuries and arrests.<ref name="heraldscotland.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/mobile/news/home-news/student-sit-in-after-police-eviction-celebrity-visits-more-protestors-and-an-upgrade-1.1092866|accessdate=31 March 2011|newspaper=Glasgow Herald}}</ref> On 12 February, council workers in [[Darlington]], including members of the unions [[UNISON]] and [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]], staged a We Love Darlington protest against council cuts in the North-East town.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/local/darlington/8851827.Unions_say_council__in_denial__over_cuts/ |title=Unions say council 'in denial' over cuts |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-03-28 |newspaper=The Northern Echo |first=Paul |last=Cook}}</ref> On 24 February a Hull City Council meeting was interrupted by protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/news/Protesters-interrupt-crucial-council-budget-meeting/article-3266039-detail/article.html |title=THE city council's budget meeting was adjourned at 5.25pm after protesters refused to leave the public gallery |publisher=Thisishullandeastriding.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> On the previous evening, a Sheffield City Council meeting was invaded by protesters over proposed cuts to local children's centres.<ref>[http://therealsteelnews.wordpress.com/2011/02/23/protest-against-cut-to-children-centres/ Protest Against Cuts to Children's Centres]; The Real Steel News; 24 February 2011</ref>
==March protests== [[File:March for the Alternative.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Demonstrators march along [[Whitehall]] on 26 March 2011.]] On 3 March, the [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] and [[UK Uncut]] held a protest on [[Knightsbridge]] against tax evasion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/414 |title=London, Knightsbridge, Thu 3rd Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> A protest was also held on the same day by UK Uncut outside the [[Barclays]] bank in Victoria Square, [[Bolton]], opposite Bolton Town Hall. The protest was against tax evasion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/395 |title=Bolton, Thu 3rd Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> On 5 March, there was a protest of around 2,000 people in Manchester about cuts being implemented on the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1410046_2000_join_march_against_public_spending_cuts_in_manchester |title=2,000 join march against public spending cuts in Manchester | Manchester Evening News |publisher=menmedia.co.uk |date=5 March 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> UK Uncut held protests in [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/428 |title=Perth, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Manchester]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/430 |title=Manchester, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Liverpool]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/413 |title=Liverpool, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Leicester]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/422 |title=Leicester, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> [[Ipswich]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/432 |title=Bristol, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> and [[Aberdeen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/433 |title=Aberdeen, Sat 5th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> Protests in Perth were against the [[Scottish Liberal Democrats]] and tax evasion; protests in [[Manchester]], [[Ipswich]], and [[Aberdeen]] were anti-austerity in general; protests in Liverpool were against the [[Big Society]]; protests in [[Leicester]] and [[Colchester]] were against tax evasion and big bonuses for bankers; protests in Edinburgh were against the closure (by the government) of two nursery schools in the city, and tax evasion; and protests in [[Bristol]] were against the closure of a library in the city. On 6 March, UK Uncut arranged to hold a protest in [[Taunton]] against government cuts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/403 |title=Taunton, Sun 6th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> UK Uncut held protests in the [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]] on 7 March, mainly around the [[Barclay's Bank]] headquarters in [[Canary Wharf]]. During the protest, a group of around a dozen people gathered in front of a sculpture in the bank lobby, and chanted, "Barclays Bank pays no tax, Tower Hamlets gets the axe," and, "Barclays, pay your tax."<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2011/mar/07/barclays-tax-protest-canary-wharf Tower Hamlets protesters vent fury over tax at Barclays headquarters]; The Guardian; 7 March 2011</ref> According to protest organizer UK Uncut, "Around twenty people, all living or working in Tower Hamlets, occupied the foyer of Barclays HQ while startled bankers were directed out a side entrance."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/438 |title=London, Tower Hamlets, Mon 7th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> UK Uncut held a protest on 9 March, at a budget cuts council meeting in the [[London Borough of Bexley]]. During the emotionally charged and noisy meeting, there were shouts of "shame" and "cutting respite care is not right" from the residents in the gallery numbering about 165, and protesters at the back doors chanted "care, not cuts" as councillors entered. Police were brought in to guard the civic offices and residents had their bags searched; those with cameras were banned from entering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/439 |title=London, Bexley, Wed 9th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref><ref>[http://www.london24.com/news/politics/fury_as_bexley_council_votes_through_35_3_million_cuts_1_825455 Fury as Bexley council votes through Â£35.3 million cuts]; London 24; 10 March 2011</ref> On 12 March, around 5,000 people marched from [[Devonshire Green]] to the venue of the 2011 Liberal Democrats spring conference, where one man was arrested for public order offences and discharge of a firework in a public place. Barricades were set up on [[Fargate]] and Surrey Street following several incidents,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-12722735 | work=BBC News | title=About 5,000 March in Lib Dem Sheffield conference protest | date=12 March 2011}}</ref> including a group of protesters running into a [[Topshop]] store on Fargate. The event has been "good-natured on the whole", police said. A large group of protesters, separate from the main group, caused violence along the march, including trying (and failing) to set fire to a police car. This group declared the day as the ''Day of Rage'',{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} and this group was clearly inspired by the [[Arab Spring]] unlike most of the recent United Kingdom protests. Much smaller protests were held by UK Uncut in [[Ipswich]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/441 |title=Ipswich, Sat 12th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> and [[Poole]], with five protesters attending the latter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/427 |title=Poole, Sat 12th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> Protesters also occerd in [[Barker's Pool]], [[Sheffield]], on the ''Day of Rage'' (12 March). UK Uncut arranged to hold anti-cuts protests in [[Basildon]] on 14 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukuncut.org.uk/actions/431 |title=Basildon, Mon 14th Mar 2011 |publisher=UK Uncut |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> On 22 March, Around 4,000 people from Universities and Colleges across [[Scotland]] marched down the [[Royal Mile]] to the [[Scottish Parliament]] and staged a rally against introduction of tuition fees and cuts to education. Politicians, student leaders and trade union representatives, including Education Secretary Mike Russell, Labour Party's Des McNulty and Margaret Smith, of the Liberal Democrats addressed the protesters at the rally.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-12819043 | work=BBC News | title=Students march to Holyrood in education protest | date=22 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/2011/03/22/students-march-on-scottish-parliament-to-urge-priority-for-education-86908-23008645/ |title=Students march on Scottish Parliament to urge priority for education |publisher=The Daily Record |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.scotsman.com/edinburgh/Fees-protest-gives-voice-to.6738951.jp | location=Edinburgh | work=The Scotsman | title=Fees protest gives voice to students | date=23 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="guardian1">[http://www.guardian.co.uk/edinburgh/2011/mar/22/edinburgh-lib-dem-student-fees-march-margaret-smith Students heckle Scottish Liberal Democrat MSP over fees]; The Guardian; 22 March 2011</ref> On the same day the University of Glasgow management evicted the [[Free Hetherington]] occupation. The occupation then moved to the University Senate, before the occupiers were eventually offered their original location back, this offer was accepted.<ref name="guardian1"/><ref name="heraldscotland.com"/> Protesters preparing ahead of the 26 March protests broke into 61 Curzon Street in London and occupied the building, calling it a "meeting place".<ref>{{cite web|last=Milan |first=Alex |url=http://www.demotix.com/news/636015/61-curzon-street-occupied-centre-march-26th-protests |title=61 Curzon Street occupied as Centre for March 26th Protests |publisher=Demotix.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-09}}</ref> On 26 March, 500,000 people attended [[2011 anti-cuts protest in London|a protest in central London]]. Further outbreaks of violence were reported in London on 27 March. Several hundred people protested in Barker's Pool, Sheffield; the branch of John Lewis was damaged by rioters throwing smoke bombs and rocks. As of 27 March 201 people have been arrested. The two men charged have been released on bail ahead of court appearances. The other 199 are being held in various police stations around London.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12876705 | work=BBC News | title=Anti-cuts demo unrest sees 149 charged | date=28 March 2011}}</ref>
==May protest== On 28 May, hundreds of protesters at 40 locations across the country staged protests against proposed cuts to the NHS. Dubbed "Emergency Operation", protesters organized by UK Uncut and trade unions converged on high street banks and held demonstrations to draw attention to the bank's role in creating the deficit.<ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/2011/05/protest-group-actions-camden UK Uncuts hosts 40 direct actions in protest at NHS reforms]; New Statesman; 29 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2011/may/28/uk-uncut-nhs-bank-protests Anti-cuts groups descend on banks in NHS protest]; Guardian News; 28 May 2011</ref>
==June J30 protest== {{Split sections|30 June 2011, "J30" protests |date=July 2011}} {{Commons category|Public sector pension protest in Britain on June 30, 2011}}
On June 30, a one-day strike, officially called "J30", was held by public sector workers to protest the government's planned uncoventional changes to pension plans and retirement policies, including raising the retirement age from 60 to 66 and the replacing of final salary pension schemes with a career-average system. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelmsfordweeklynews.co.uk/news/9117023.Teachers_march_through_Chelmsford_in_protest/?ref=mmsp |title=Teachers march through Chelmsford in protest (From Chelmsford Weekly News) |publisher=Chelmsfordweeklynews.co.uk |date=1 July 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref name="cambridge-news1">{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Royston/Most-schools-to-shut-down-today-30062011.htm |title=Royston News | Latest News & Events In Royston, Cambridgeshire | Royston Evening News | Most schools to shut down today |publisher=Cambridge-news.co.uk |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-06}}</ref><ref name="southwalesargus2">{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/9113171.STRIKE__Thousands_to_walk_out_in_day_of_action/ |title=STRIKE: Gwent hit by day of action (From South Wales Argus) |publisher=Southwalesargus.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-03}}</ref> The [[Driving Standards Agency]] had recently announced that it was to launch a localised trial to determine whether delivering examiners from ''non-established'' test centres could help with growing pupil demand, starting in [[Warrington]], [[Wiltshire]], [[Ayrshire]], [[Wales]] and [[Dumbarton]]. <ref name="trl1">[http://www.trl.co.uk/trl-news-hub/transport-news/latest-transport-news/majority-of-driving-examiners-attended-work-during-strikes_800610142.htm TRL - Majority of driving examiners 'attended work during strikes' - Latest Transport News - Transport News - TRL News Hub]</ref>
In the one-day strike, pickets and a series of anti-cuts rallies by the National Union of Teachers (NUT), Association of Teachers and Lecturers (ATL), University and College Union (UCU) and the Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS) went ahead largely as planned. Over 11,000 schools in [[England]] were affected by the strike, according to the data released by the Department for Education (DfE). <ref name="periscopepost">{{cite web|url=http://www.periscopepost.com/2011/07/public-sector-strikes-come-and-go-but-is-this-the-beginning-of-a-longer-battle/ |title=Public sector strikes come and go, but is this the beginning of a longer battle? |publisher=The Periscope Post |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref><ref name="periscopepost"/> Nearly 400 schools were closed in greater [[Birmingham]] and the [[Black Country]], with another 70 partially shut. According to union reports, across the rest of England, 3,200 schools were shut and 2,200 were partially closed, out of about 22,000 state-funded schools. <ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-13967903 |title=BBC News â Birmingham strike rally: Hundreds protest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 30 June 2011|accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> Only 18 out of 750 [[Jobcentre Plus]] offices in the country were closed due to the lack of strike activity by their staff, while 90% of the civilian call centre staff at the Metropolitan Police did strike. The Coastguard also reported some minor walkouts. <ref name="periscopepost" /> According to the Department for Transport, some 76 per cent of [[driving examiner]]s went to work.<ref name="trl1"/> Approximately 180 prison office staff and workshop instructors mounted a picket line outside HMP [[Gartree Prison]] near the town of [[Market Harborough]]. <ref name="thisisleicestershire1">{{cite web|author=by Semazasez |url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Public-services-standstill-strikes-hit/story-12862281-detail/story.html |title=Public services at a standstill as strikes hit Leicestershire |publisher=This is Leicestershire |date=23 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref> The event was officially called the "J30"<ref name="periscopepost"/> after the date it was held on.
===Greater London=== [[File:The march.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Striking teachers and public sector workers march down the Kingsway, London, flanked by police on 30 June 2011.<ref name="dailymail1"/><ref name="dailymail1"/>]]
The main march and [[Trades Union]] events were in central London on the 30th and attracted 15,000 to 20,000 people to their cause.<ref>{{cite web|author=Published on Tue 28 Jun 03:57:37 BST 2011 |url=http://www.banburyguardian.co.uk/news/national/pension_talks_fail_to_stop_strikes_1_2806981 |title=Pension talks fail to stop strikes â National |publisher=Banbury Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.banburycake.co.uk/news/national/9116109.print/ |title=Overtime ban follows day of strikes (From Banbury Cake) |publisher=Banburycake.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref><ref name="dailymail1"/><ref name="periscopepost"/><ref name="dailymail1"/> At one point public service employees marched past [[Big Ben]] and the [[Palace of Westminster]] during their rally<ref name="belfasttelegraph1"/> There were marches and picket lines across London including at the [[Old Bailey]].<ref name="mirror1"/> [[Camden Town]] and [[Marylebone]] saw a few Camden Council employees hold a local [[strike action|strike]] and [[Picketing (protest)|picket]] over the council's employment terms.{{cn|date=September 2011}} There were queues at Border Control in [[Heathrow Airport]]'s Terminal Five as some of the immigration and customs staff joined the strike. <ref name="southwalesargus1">{{cite web|url=http://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/9113171.STRIKE__Thousands_to_walk_out_in_day_of_action/ |title=STRIKE: Gwent hit by day of action (From South Wales Argus) |publisher=Southwalesargus.co.uk |date=30 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref> Pickets targeted the head office of the department for Communities and Local Government in central London and stopped around 20 people from crossing one of the [[picket (protesting)|picket lines]] at Eland House. <ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/local-government-network/2011/jun/30/clg-hit-by-strikes CLG head office hit by strikes | Local government network | Guardian Professional]</ref>
There were 35 arrests in central London and 2 in outer London.<ref name="dailymail1"/> Arrests were made in [[Whitehall]] as police and protesters clashed.<ref>{{cite news|author=5:31PM BST 30 Jun 2011 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newsvideo/uk-politics-video/8609056/Police-and-protesters-clash-in-London-during-public-sector-strikes.html |title=Video: Police and protesters clash in London during public sector strikes |publisher=Telegraph |date=7 March 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-03}}</ref>
===South East England=== [[File:NUT Sussex Division - J30.jpg|thumb|right|200px|30 June protestors in Brighton from the National Union of Teachers (NUT).]]

[[File:Chatham Pension Rally- EMA 7461.JPG| thumb|right|200px|Nine rallies were held in Kent, this was the one at the [[Command House]] in [[Chatham, Kent|Chatham]]. Glasgow Sheriff Court was picketed.<ref name="scotsman1">{{cite web|last=Brown |first=Craig |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/Scotland-escapes-the-worst-effects.6794020.jp |title=Scotland escapes the worst effects of UK strike action |publisher=Scotsman.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref><ref name="stornaway">[http://www.stornowaygazette.co.uk/news/scottish-headlines/30_000_join_strikes_across_scotland_1_1705919 30,000 join strikes across Scotland - Scottish Headlines - Stornoway Gazette]</ref> A rally was held in [[Glasgow]]'s George Square that included members of the [[UNITE]] union, University, College Union and PCS members.<ref name="scotsman1"/>
A minor rally took place at The Mound in [[Edinburgh]], while picket lines were formed outside Edinburgh Castle, the Scottish Parliament and outside the government headquarters at St Andrew's House, Edinburgh <ref name="scotsman1"/> The PCS claimed that 90% of its 30,000 Scottish members took part in the day of action. <ref name="scotsman1"/>
The DVLA was shut in [[Glasgow]], [[Dundee]] and [[Inverness]], while [[Edinburgh]] and Aberdeen had reduced service.<ref name="scotsman1"/>
The [[Scottish Courts Service]] reckoned that about 30% of its 1,622 staff had not gone to work, the Department for Work and Pensions said that the jobcentres in [[Kirkwall]], [[Lerwick]], [[Cambuslang]] and [[Rutherglen]] were closed.<ref name="stornaway" />
There were picket lines at [[Faslane]] naval base.<ref name="mirror1"/>

The staff in local government departments and agencies including HM Revenue & Customs, [[UK Border Agency]], NI Courts Service, Maritime & Coastguards Agency, Identity & Passport Services, [[Belfast International Airport]], the [[Passport Office]] the [[British Council]], the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]], Tax offices and courts. Most of this action was focused on [[Belfast]].<ref name="belfasttelegraph2">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/northern-ireland-to-escape-major-disruption-in-day-of-strikes-16017744.html#ixzz1QxOrefY1 |title=Northern Ireland to escape major disruption in day of strikes â Northern Ireland, Local & National |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-03}}</ref><ref name="insideirelandcivil">{{cite web|last=Davison |first=Stephanie |url=http://insideireland.ie/2011/06/30/ni-civil-servants-on-strike-23295/ |title=NI civil servants on strike Â» Inside Ireland |publisher=Insideireland.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-07-03}}</ref><ref name="newstalkcivil">{{cite web|url=http://www.newstalk.ie/2011/news/3000-civil-servants-strike-in-the-north/ |title=3,000 civil servants strike in the North |publisher=Newstalk.ie |date= |accessdate=2011-07-03}}</ref>
[[Belfast International Airport]] and several government offices were picketed and had partial [[strike action|walk outs]] as a [[trades union]] rally took place in the city centre.<ref name="belfasttelegraph2"/><ref name="insideirelandcivil"/><ref name="newstalkcivil"/>
PCS [[Picketing (protest)|picketing]] was also be mounted outside government offices in [[Enniskillen]], [[Derry]], [[Coleraine]], and [[Newry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/northern-ireland-to-escape-major-disruption-in-day-of-strikes-16017744.html#ixzz1QxQT05D1 |title=Northern Ireland to escape major disruption in day of strikes â Northern Ireland, Local & National |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-03}}</ref>
==July protest== The "J30" events were to be followed by a partial one-day overtime ban on 1 July. <ref name="belfasttelegraph1">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/uk/overtime-ban-follows-day-of-strikes-16018253.html |title=Overtime ban follows day of strikes - UK, Local & National |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> The PCS chose to have a month-long overtime ban instead <ref>{{cite news|author=Kate McCann |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/local-government-network/2011/jul/01/pcs-union-announces-overtime-ban |title=Union announces ban on month-long overtime | Local government network | Guardian Professional |publisher=Guardian |date= 1 July 2011|accessdate=2011-07-01 |location=London}}</ref> The pension cuts and reforms were, like the planned budget cuts in the [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] and Education budget, the main causes of the union's simmering malcontent with the [[Cameron Ministry|government of that time]].<ref name="worcesternews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/news/9117126.Hundreds_join_strikes_over_pension_proposals/ |title=Hundreds join strikes over pension proposals (From Worcester News) |publisher=Worcesternews.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref> The government commented later that day and on 1 June that they thought the strike had failed to live up to what the unions had claimed would have been on the 29th. <ref name="dailymail1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2010086/Public-sector-strike-Union-leaders-insist-walkout-best-response.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title=Public sector strike: Union leaders insist walkout was 'best ever' response | Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-01 |location=London}}</ref> The UNISON union warned of further [[strike action]] in [[Birmingham]]. <ref name="birminghampost1">{{cite web|last=Keogh |first=Kat |url=http://www.birminghampost.net/news/west-midlands-news/2011/06/30/union-warns-of-further-strikes-in-birmingham-65233-28966281/ |title=Union warns of further strikes in Birmingham - West Midlands News - News |publisher=Birmingham Post |date=28 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
==November 30 strikes== {{main|2011 UK public sector strikes}} An additional one-day strike took place across the country on 30 November. The strike was organised by various unions with the [[Trade Union Congress]] calling it the biggest strike in a generation. Nearly two-thirds of England's 21,476 schools were closed, all but 33 of Scotland's 2,700 states schools were closed and 7,000 operations in hospitals were cancelled. Twenty-one arrests were made, as [[Occupy London]] activists marched from Piccadilly Circus to Panton House, the headquarters of international mining company [[Xstrata]], where the highest paid CEO in the [[United Kingdom]] works. The activists entered the building with a large banner saying "All power to the 99%" and subsequently entered onto the rooftop and strapped the banner to the front of the building. Videos of the violent arrests were posted on social-video site [[YouTube]], including a video showing an undercover police officer, tasked with infiltrating the [[Occupy London]] march. A total of 75 activist-related arrests were logged in the capital that day.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15953806 |title=Public sector strike rallies held across UK |date=2011-11-30 |accessdate=2011-11-30 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
==Public opinion== {{Expand section|date=July 2011}} A [[YouGov]] poll, published 26 March 2011, found that a 52% majority supported the protests "to campaign against public sector spending cuts" while 31% expressed opposition. 55% of voters believe that the cuts are necessary, against 32% who think they are unnecessary, but most feel the cuts are too deep and too fast. The same YouGov poll showed that 38% blame Labour for the cuts, 23% blame the coalition and 26% blame both. The results contained a strong partisan divide, with 83% of Labour supporters and only 19% of Tory supporters backing the protests. [[YouGov]] had surveyed 2,720 adults online between 20â21 March 2011.<ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/the-staggers/2011/03/cuts-blame-public-economy How unpopular are the cuts now?]; New Statesman; 25 March 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuc.org.uk/industrial/tuc-19397-f0.cfm|title=Majority back aims of TUC March for the Alternative|date=25 March 2011|publisher=[[Trades Union Congress]]|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
However, a Reuters/Ipsos MORI poll in June 2011 found around an even divide over whether public sector workers are right to strike about cuts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://main.omanobserver.om/node/56468 |title=Strike in Britain as protests hit Europe | Oman Observer |publisher=Main.omanobserver.om |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref>
==Responses==
{{See also|Occupy movement}}
[[Secretary of State for Education|Education Secretary]] [[Michael Gove]] said on [[Today (BBC Radio 4)|BBC's Radio 4 Today]] early on the morning of 26 March , "Of course people will feel a sense of disquiet, in some cases anger, at what they see happening, but the difficulty we have as the Government inheriting a terrible economic mess, is that we have to take steps to bring the public finances back into balance." He also speculated that the march could "move from being [a] family event into being something darker".<ref name=live/>
[[Daniel Hannan]], a journalist and the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] for [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]], stated that the protesters "have decided to indulge their penchant for empty, futile, self-righteous indignation." He wrote, "After âNo Cuts!â the marchersâ favourite slogan was âFairness!â Alright, then... How about being fair to our children, whom we have freighted with a debt unprecedented in peacetime?"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/danielhannan/100081436/march-for-the-alternative-what-alternative/|title='March for the Alternative'? WHAT alternative?|author=[[Daniel Hannan]]|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|location=London}}</ref>
[[Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Nick Clegg]] told [[Reuters]] news service, "If I was a demonstrator in London, I would be furious with the Labour leadership, because they are whipping up people's fervour and they are being utterly dishonest... We have an opposition party that has retreated into the worst kind of infantile opposition politics, which is to score lots of tactical points and not level with people about what they would do instead."<ref name=clegg>{{Cite news|title=Clegg says Labour dishonestly stoking cuts protest|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/03/26/uk-britain-protests-clegg-idUKTRE72P0AZ20110326|publisher=Reuters|date=26 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
The [[Home Secretary]], [[Theresa May]], told Parliament that she would consult the police on giving them new powers to remove face coverings and [[Balaclava (clothing)|balaclavas]]. As well as banning orders, similar to those used to ban [[Football hooliganism|football hooligans]] from football matches. The [[Shadow Home Secretary]], [[Yvette Cooper]], strongly backed the minister's stance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Home Secretary Theresa May condemns protest 'thugs'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12881734|accessdate=30 March 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=28 March 2011}}</ref>
In ''[[Gulf News]]'', columnist Dr. Ayman Mustafa remarked about anti-austerity strikes and protests that "People still see the financial sector not being punished although it was the main culprit of the financial crisis and the subsequent recession". He also wrote that "most of the government cuts are targeting workers, while big businesses and financial businesses in particular are being incentivised with the clichÃ© that Britain must encourage bankers and fund managers to stay".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/business/opinion/london-faces-a-summer-of-strike-chaos-over-austerity-1.829578 |title=London faces a summer of strike chaos over austerity |publisher=gulfnews |date= |accessdate=2011-07-01}}</ref>
